statement:
Let $X$ a real Banach space and $F \in C^{1}(X,\mathbb{R})$. Consider
$K$ a compact metric space, and $K^{*} \subset K$ a closed nonempty
subset of $K$. If $p^{*} : K^{*} \rightarrow X$ is a continuous mapping,
set
$$\mathcal{P} = \{ p \in C(K, \, X); \; p = p^{*} \; \textrm{on } K^{*} \}.$$

Define $$c = \inf_{p \in \mathcal{P}} \max_{t \in K} F(p(t)).$$

Assume that $$\label{eq1}
c > \max_{t \in K^{*}} F(p^{*}(t)).$$ Then there exists a sequence
$(x_{n})$ in $X$ such that

1.  $\lim\limits_{n \rightarrow \infty} F(x_{n}) = c$;

2.  $\lim\limits_{n \rightarrow \infty} \| F'(x_{n})\|  = 0$.

The name of this theorem is a consequence of a simplified visualization
for the objects from theorem. If we consider the set
$K^{*} = \{ A, \, B\}$, where $A$ and $B$ are two villages,
$\mathcal{P}$ is the set of all the routes from $A$ to $B$, and $F(x)$
represents the altitude of point $x$; then the assumption (\[eq1\]) is
equivalent to say that the villages $A$ and $B$ are separated with a
mountains chain. So, the conclusion of the theorem tell us that exists a
route between the villages with a minimal altitude. With other words
exists a “mountain pass” .
